Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
The lunch rush is in full swing, and I’m moving quickly behind the register, greeting each customer with a smile. My manager always says, “Friendly service keeps them coming back,” so I make sure to chat, even as the line grows. I notice my coworkers glancing at the clock, reminding me that the office function is just a couple of hours away. I remember the email: “Dress business casual—no uniforms, please.” 

As a Muslim, I always wear loose, long-sleeved tops and a hijab, even under my work vest. But the suggested dress code for the function is more relaxed, and I overheard some colleagues planning to wear short sleeves and fitted skirts. I feel the pressure to fit in, to be approachable and part of the team, especially since I’m still new here. At the same time, I know my faith asks me to dress modestly, regardless of the occasion. 

I can already imagine the curious looks if I show up in my usual attire, and the awkward questions that might follow. My heart pounds as I ring up another customer, torn between wanting to belong and staying true to my beliefs.
